title: Caution Midi Health is NOT personalized care
paragraph: MIDI Health touts personalized healthcare for women, but I'm glad I followed my instincts and sought another opinion. I met with one of the MIDI practitioners and reviewed all of my symptoms. She was very quick to suggest I go on a low dose estrogen patch and progesterone pills. When I inquired about a blood panel to ensure this was the proper direction for my healthcare, as well as understanding what dosage I needed, she said we can certainly do that but it will not dictate or change our action plan. When I asked her to elaborate she said we are treating your symptoms and so regardless what your blood test would say it would not change my recommendation, but if it makes you feel better I can order your labs. Regardless, we will start you on a low dose and meet every few weeks to see how you're feeling, and then we would increase that subsequent dose if your symptoms are not improving. She also suggested how much this hormone replacement would solve for other symptoms that I didn't even have, which was also a red flag. Her lack of personalization and then suggesting blood work wasn't relevant, was a major pause for me. I decided to seek out another health care partner that specialized in women's health care, but based their recommendations on your blood work for a more personalized approach. In my consult with my new practitioner they said you can absolutely tell how much hormone replacement a person needs based on what their levels are at the point they had the blood taken within their cycle, so you would absolutely be able to more personalize a dosage if that is even needed at all. They also said it's extremely dangerous for women to be prescribed HRT without blood work to confirm if and what is needed. When my blood work came back I found out that I actually have an autoimmune disorder with my thyroid as my underlying condition to all the symptoms I experienced. And guess what, my estrogen and progesterone levels are completely normal!! The only sex hormone in question is that my testosterone levels are a little low, so not quite optimal but technically within range. All of this is to say that if I had stayed with MIDI I would have been mistreated with a hormone supplement that was not needed at all. In fact, my new physician care suggested that had they put me on estrogen and continue to increase the dosage, which was not needed, it would have made my thyroid situation far worse because estrogen imbalance also can accelerate hypothyroidism, causing me more harm and making it much harder to get under control. I just want to send a caution for anyone seeking support through MIDI Health, thinking you will get personalized health care. They are looking for symptoms that "could" mean you have a decline in estrogen or progesterone, and they will treat your symptoms on that premise only but not actually look for the root cause to really help your long-term health. I was extremely disappointed to know that had I not been an advocate for my own health care, I would have been prescribed drugs that were absolutely unnecessary and would have caused me more harm. A lot of symptoms we experience in our bodies can mimic a decline in estrogen or other sex hormones, it doesn't mean that's the actual problem so I highly suggest women get blood work first before allowing people to prescribe them unnecessary medication. I'm thankful that now I'm on the path to restore my health and addressing the thyroid issue that was truly the underlying cause of my symptoms. Midi is clearly out to prescribe as much hormone replacement drugs to as many women as possible for financial gain. If they can fit your symptoms into their box of even the possibility that you would benefit from their prescription, you will be offered it no questions asked. Secondarily, they said my insurance would not cover my $250 visit and continue to send me a bill. I had to contact the billing office multiple times to tell them to send it through my insurance and if it is not covered I will take care of it. Turns out my insurance did cover it after all, So if nothing else I'm glad I didn't lose the $250 out of pocket to this company. Take charge of your health and be your own advocate, get your blood work to confirm it's actually what you need!

title: As a woman in her late 40s who is…
paragraph: As a woman in her late 40s who is experiencing increasing menopausal symptoms, I was eager to try Midi Health, as I understood that this practice specializes in women's health care from peri- through post-menopause. Unfortunately, so far, I have been dissatisfied with the level of care and attention that I have received from Midi Health's practitioners. My initial consult with an NP was fine. At the end of the consult, the NP told me that she'd need to order labs for me before I started taking HRT, but she needed to know which lab.  Minutes after the consult ended, I messaged the NP to provide the specific lab and location. Two weeks later, I'd heard nothing from the NP or Midi Health about the lab order. I had to dig around on the (very basic, not user friendly) website to determine whether my labs had ever been ordered. When it appeared they had not, I messaged the NP to inquire. She then apologized and ordered the labs. If that had been the only negative experience, no big deal. But it only got worse from there. When I printed out the lab order to take to my lab, I noticed that the NP hadn't ordered a hormone panel. But she had ordered a bunch of other general tests, like Vitamin D and cholesterol. I thought that was odd; wasn't the whole point to get a baseline on my hormone levels before I started HRT? But since I'm not a medical professional, I again messaged my NP to ask.  It turned out that the original NP was on vacation, so a different person was covering for her.  That person responded that no, a hormone panel wasn't necessary, and attached a long scientific "treatise" to prove it. I thought that was a little odd, but okay.... she's a medical professional and I am not. At my next consultation with my NP, who had by then returned from vacation, it was immediately obvious that she hadn't reviewed my lab results before the call started. After I mentioned that I had taken the labs and results were in, she wasted 5 minutes of our session reviewing them.When the NP mentioned that there was no hormone panel result, I inwardly rolled my eyes. "You didn't order one," I replied, "and when I asked your covering NP about whether the panel had been omitted in error, she said it wasn't necessary." The NP looked at me blankly, responding: "It's a good idea to order a hormone panel to establish a baseline level before you start HRT."Oh, is it? Then why did: (1) You not order that panel, and (2) your covering NP tell me it was actually NOT advised (the opposite of what you're saying now)?So now I have to go back to the lab to take yet another panel.
